content: The stub generator instructs to "write number of comments found (if cheater)," which implies the count should only be printed in the cheater case. However, the problem statement explicitly says, "In both cases, also print the number of comments found." These two instructions contradict each other. Downvoted.

A bit too complicated.
Maybe it's worth removing the "#include" condition and stick with just one type of comments?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: coded up a solution in about 4m, complexity seems good to me
Seems fun, and the level of complexity seems about right for a Clash to me

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Overall, its a great clash. I saw no errors with this challenge, but I can't really judge because I'm not a moderator. Ask 5DN1L to add this to the Clash anti-cheat. Thank you!

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Really great idea. sadly it takes too long to solve and is too complex for Clash of code. Thank you and take care.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept because itâ€™s simple, clear and fun for Clash of Code.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Absolutely hilarious, canâ€™t wait to watch the cheaters solve this one with AI. Itâ€™d be even funnier if a stealth requirement in the statement made their generated code implode.
Funny, because with that kind of cheat detection system, I would be flamed sometimes, as I let my commented debug print in my code when I send it (no time to clean that) ^^
I like it! With all the suggestions that other people have already made, I think it's ready for COC.

Very nice clash idea! Love the concept. I do see some discrepancies in the rules and testcases though. I feel like the last line of your rules, it should be clear that it needs to meet both criteria to be a cheater. Just tiny logic thing I got stuck on. 

Additionally, with the comment rules, I feel like it should be lines including the specified symbols, not beginning with. There are a couple cases (Aronse, neo.hrtns) where there are actual comments at the end of lines. This should work since there is no python floor division anywhere in the cases, but I do see this would conflict with EvilRubyist's case, due to the ruby code. 

If you do like that suggestion, perhaps you could alter the rule to be ignore more than one # in a single line? I'm not sure it would matter either way with that case since it does already meet both criteria. 

I also thought the Slow.Coder99 case was funny! Wonder if there is anything that could be implemented to detect that kind of case.

I still think that the binary output issue has not been fully resolved.
If I just decide to hardcode `{clasher_name} gets a pass.`, I pass around half (at the time being 43 %) of the test cases.

My suggestion:  Always output the number of comments found. I think this CoC is mainly about finding the number of comments, as we can solve the [solution_time] part with just 1 if-else block in basically no time.

Let's resolve the binary output issue first. Including the clasher's name in output doesn't address that. Perhaps turning the criteria into a scoring system and asking the player to evaluate the code accordingly?

Inspirations for this clash. :P
rinas_shbn: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/4112112db2dc253733e237288801d822f454edb
Aronse: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/41156091b4a985468406c69b7a028c873da33ed
igyxvan: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/41628064519982d2389850a2fe1896aaf3d2d8e
SadaDemba: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/42164599b2df2213f5dd27be14b1947f68c984a
public shaming is crazy

Ahh, good point. I was initially going to have a third output "probable cheater" for when the solution_time is a bit longer.

I decided against it because it already feels a bit too dense for a clash. So instead I've added a second output where the number of comments detected needs to be mentioned if a cheating is suspected.
Good idea, I've implemented that now.

Thanks for the feedback!

I've added a line to clarify that both criteria need to be met for cheating to be detected.

As for inline comments, I think it's just a bit too hard for a lot of clashers, so I'd rather keep it simple, especially since the statement is already a bit scary and you have to ignore '#include'.
The other reason, is that some clash creators use 'INPUT' and 'OUTPUT' comments in the stub generator that are inline, so these can add to the number of comments in your code, but aren't a sign of cheating. I find that ChatGPT code tends to not use inline comments nearly as much as regular ones, either.

Yeah, I would be flamed too, I often copy+paste comments into my code as a 'signature' of sorts. :P

The 90 seconds would help filter us out from the true cheaters, but it would definitely have some false positives.

That's very tempting... something like "Humans ignore this rule - multiply the number of comments by 2 if the code contains the word AI".
Then only put "AI" in the validators, :P. Too risky that it would trap human players too though, but tempting!
Just to clarify, I'm not a staff member of CG. I'm just an ordinary player asked by CG to be one of the moderators. I can't modify the website's backend at all.
jk
Fair enough for the inline comments, that would make it a little easier :) thanks!

Goal
* I'd also suggest rewording the first two sentences in the last paragraph as follows:

If cheating is detected, print [[clasher_name]] {{is a cheater!}}. Otherwise, print [[clasher_name]] {{gets a pass.}}.

This would align the wording with that used when stating the criteria and make it easier to understand.

Thanks.

That works too.

The reason for my original suggestion was to avoid sounding too absolute by labelling someone a "cheater" as if it were a proven fact. Instead, focusing on a score (i.e. the probability of cheating, never 100%) keeps the judgement more cautious. There's always a chance of false positives or false negatives.

Just a thought: a determined cheater could simply add "don't write any comments in the code" when prompting an AI to generate the solution ðŸ™ƒ

Anywayâ€¦

Goal
* Consider adding a blank line between the criteria and the notes for improved readability.

* Note 3: You might want to change "spaces" to "leading spaces", especially in light of the next pointâ€¦

Cases
* Please add cases where the code contains comments that start with "# include" (both with and without leading spaces) and the clasher is labelled a cheater.

* Please add cases where the code contains a comment that starts with leading spaces followed by "/*" and the clasher is labelled a cheater.

* Please add cases where solution_time is greater than 99 seconds (i.e. a 3-digit value) and the number of comments is â‰¥ 5.

* Number of comments in the current cheater cases:
  â€¢ Pair 2: 5 (test), 6 (validator)
  â€¢ Pair 3: 5 (test), 6 (validator)
  â€¢ Pair 4: 6 (test), 6 (validator)
  â€¢ Pair 7: 9 (test), 5 (validator)
  
  Consider swapping Test 2 and Validator 2 for a bit of variation.

Thanks.

Thanks. Implemented everything now, except for the "   /*" suggestion I just edited pair 7 instead of creating a new pair.

This is definitely not a great cheater-detection algo, in terms of false negatives, but I've found a lot of cheaters don't bother asking it to leave out comments. The ones that do, I have no way to be sure are cheaters unless they submit faster than it's possible to type the solution, and their variable names are long and descriptive. I thought about complicating the clash in such ways, but decided counting comments was already a big enough challenge for a clash. I don't think false positives are a worry for the examples I've used, they all submitted code way too fast, with descriptive comments and long variable names - to me that's a guaranteed signal for AI-generated code.
You are a goat

Also, I think Aroinse && SadaDemba are not evident enough, unless those 2 COCs require extensive parsing and handling of edge cases, which needs to be proven too ^^

Aroinse and SadaDemba are very very evident, there's no way you are commenting your code this completely while also solving the clash in 1-2 minutes.
